Um, so just to kind of sum up that
concept, you know, if pre Unreal Engine
previs is is working in Maya, obviously
most years have a pipeline of some sort.
So it's a little bit easier to manage.
But you'll generally open a shot, work
on that shot, exit the shot or render,
exit the shot, open the next shot,
repeat until you have all your shots.
Then you you pull them all together and
edit later and check, ah, is it? Oh,
this kind of oh, I didn't really think
about how that edit will affect that
shot or the energy flow from shot A to
shot B is wrong, so now I need to go
back. You're kind of missing this
context and it ends up creating this
weird cycle of of iterating then viewing
iterating then viewing separately. It
creates a really long uh feedback loop,
I would say. you know, you're waiting
for notes via email or Slack or you have
a one a week once a week uh review with
director and it ends up making you feel
a little bit like even though Beavers is
is a very uh fundamental part of film
making, you're kind of off to the side
of the film being made and then you you
pop your head in and go, "Oh, hey." And
then you leave and go and make the film
and then pop your head in. You know,
it's a bit strange for me. Whereas post
Unreal Engine previs, which for any of
you who's done previs or cinematic work,
you get to do it all in the one editor,
which is amazing. You have real-time
iterate iteration. So if you're sitting
there with the DP or the director next
to you or sitting on Zoom, there's no
need to wait for an email to come back
in a week if they have time. It's just
they can respond. You can organically
kind of find shots together. Uh it has
this real kind of like being in the room
kind of feeling even when you're working
remotely. and it makes it fun and
spontaneous. And due to the really, you
know, beautiful visuals of Unreal Engine
compared to something like Maya, there's
also a lot more of this natural instinct
and and inspiration of like, oh, I let's
let's come out behind this little shrub
or, you know, there's a natural
chemistry to it, let's say.
